goal: S1 σ under 0.40s and average under 28.0s

preferences: Responds well to having feelings validated by data

session_history.focus_area: Sector 1 (Entry Phase) - 1.61s loss per lap, highest variance
session_history.notes: First session of Season 01 2026. Track completely new. Technical, karting-like. No white lines for reference except center dotted lines. Tricky last corner and esses section. S2 is already solid (0.55s loss). S1 and S3 are the big opportunities.

session_history.focus_area: Sector 1 (Entry Phase) - 0.61s loss per lap, σ = 0.66s
session_history.notes: Second session of the day (3 hours after first). Paradox session: Objectively faster (0.3s improvement) and WAY more consistent (6x improvement in σ), but Master Lonn felt 'all over the place' and 'no feel'. Classic overdriving symptom. S2 is locked in (0.28s loss, σ = 0.19s). Key insight: Can't brute-force feel. Need to dial back to 95% and build rhythm first. The disconnect between objective improvement and subjective feeling is strong.

session_history.focus_area: Sector 1 (Entry Phase) - 0.58s loss per lap, σ = 0.50s
session_history.notes: BREAKTHROUGH SESSION: Master Lonn consciously chose NOT to overdrive and it WORKED. S1 consistency improved (0.66s → 0.50s σ), incidents cut in HALF (39 → 18), and most importantly - IT FELT BETTER. Overall σ went up (0.86s → 1.81s) because S2 fell apart (0.19s → 1.19s σ), but this is the cost of focused learning. Can't hold everything perfect while rewiring one corner. Key insight: Master Lonn recognized 'not overdriving' in real-time - internal calibration is developing. The paradox reversed: Less consistent overall but FELT better because the improvement was intentional. PB of 50.985s (sub-51!) achieved through control, not chaos.

insights: Master Lonn is new to Summit Point Jefferson
Track positioning is challenging without clear white lines
Using center dotted lines as reference points
Eager to learn and improve pace
Asks the right questions about improvement
CRITICAL INSIGHT: Master Lonn experiences 'feel disconnect' when overdriving - lap times improve but confidence tanks
Pushing harder doesn't always equal better results for ADHD drivers - need rhythm and reference points
Master Lonn's brain needs the mental model to match physical execution or it feels chaotic
BREAKTHROUGH: Master Lonn can now RECOGNIZE when he's overdriving in real-time - internal calibration developing!
Focused practice works: When told to focus on S1, he improved S1 (24% better σ) even if other sectors got messy
For ADHD brain: Better to improve ONE thing intentionally than try to hold everything perfect
Master Lonn values FEEL over pure lap time - sustainable for long-term improvement
Discipline is improving: Incidents cut in half when not overdriving
S1 consistency trend: 1.07s → 0.66s → 0.50s (steady improvement across 3 sessions)
Trade-off is real: S2 went from locked-in (0.19s σ) to messy (1.19s σ) while fixing S1 - this is expected
Master Lonn doesn't get discouraged by temporary messiness in unfocused areas - good mental approach
next_steps: Continue S1 focus - you're at 0.50s σ, push to 0.40s (locking it in)
Maintain the 'not overdriving' feel - that's the secret sauce
Goal: 5 consecutive laps where S1 is within 0.2s of each other
Don't stress about S2 messiness - it'll come back once S1 is bulletproof
Once S1 is locked (σ < 0.40s), THEN bring S2 back from vacation
Keep using the internal calibration you're developing ('Am I overdriving right now?')
Remember: Speed through control, not chaos
